text:
We do a ton of pre-recording prep with guests, which has helped us secure amazing SMEs at some very large organizations (FEMA, Weather Channel, American Foundation for Suicide Prevention, etc.).

Probably my favorite thing we’ve done is create the attached Overview doc. This is probably obvious to folks in this community, but you’d be surprised how many podcasts are totally unprofessional - no follow through, nothing guests can share internally to get approval, etc. Having a resource that answers the most obvious questions upfront has saved us a ton of time.

elements.text:

text: Hey all. I'm a one person marketing team trying to repurpose content for as many social channels as possible (YouTube, podcast, article, Tweet thread, TikTok, Instagram, LinkedIn post, etc). Has anyone here done that or something similar? If so, do you have any tips for streamlining something like that?

elements.text: Hey all. I'm a one person marketing team trying to repurpose content for as many social channels as possible (YouTube, podcast, article, Tweet thread, TikTok, Instagram, LinkedIn post, etc). Has anyone here done that or something similar? If so, do you have any tips for streamlining something like that?

text:
There may be an app, but I do this by hand for our LinkedIn and Twitter channels. I have a folder called “Social uploads” with subfolders for different content pieces. For a video, for example, I have these four files:
• Text file containing video title (for LinkedIn) and post copy (text, hashtags, and URL if any)
• Video file itself (MP4)
• Captions file (SRT)
• Preview image (PNG) for LinkedIn

elements.text: There may be an app, but I do this by hand for our LinkedIn and Twitter channels. I have a folder called “Social uploads” with subfolders for different content pieces. For a video, for example, I have these four files:
Text file containing video title (for LinkedIn) and post copy (text, hashtags, and URL if any)
Video file itself (MP4)
Captions file (SRT)
Preview image (PNG) for LinkedIn

text:
This is a very specific question, but have any of you managed the LinkedIn page of a company that got acquired? What did you do with it?

Our company Perspectium got bought by BitTitan this year. We do want to keep the Perspectium page (many of our followers may not have an interest in other BitTitan products). But we’re also wanting to present a unified BitTitan brand, so linking our two pages in some way would be great. I see from <https://www.linkedin.com/help/lms/answer/54563/acquired-linkedin-pages|this LinkedIn article> that one possibility is requesting that LinkedIn assign the Perspectium page as an affiliate page of BitTitan. That would be fine, except that a banner will appear saying, “Perspectium was acquired by BitTitan. To see what’s new, visit BitTitan.” So we may lose followers to the BitTitan page who are specifically interested in following the Perspectium product.

I’d be interested in hearing what happened with your company’s page after your company got bought by another company.

attachments.title: Acquired LinkedIn Pages | Marketing Solutions Help
attachments.text: Marketing Solutions Help - Acquired LinkedIn Pages - How can a Page be updated to indicate it has been acquired by another organization?
attachments.fallback: Marketing Solutions Help: Acquired LinkedIn Pages | Marketing Solutions Help

I’d be interested in hearing what happened with your company’s page after your company got bought by another company.

text:
<https://vimeo.com/create|vimeo create> lets you make social videos for instagram stories/feed, twitter, facebook, tiktok, etc. from 1 place

you essentially create your video using a template (or from scratch), and then magical robots format it into square, 16:9, etc. with animations and music as needed

i think canva may also have a similar tool for video creation

(disclosure, i work for vimeo)

i think canva may also have a similar tool for video creation

text: <@U028781SL6P> I've onboarded and trained  over 50 writers in the last 6 months. I summarised some general lessons on LinkedIn (screenshot below).

elements.text: I've onboarded and trained  over 50 writers in the last 6 months. I summarised some general lessons on LinkedIn (screenshot below).

text: • what topics do we cover? week 1: get to know the company. week 2: go through our inhouse writing process step by step; week 3: use our inhouse software; week 4: customer management best practices; week 5: ideation/having good ideas

elements.text: what topics do we cover? week 1: get to know the company. week 2: go through our inhouse writing process step by step; week 3: use our inhouse software; week 4: customer management best practices; week 5: ideation/having good ideas

text: We don't teach anything about SEO or interpreting briefs in onboarding, and tbh that's something I want to change. Briefs are a huge area of opportunity for a lot of writers

elements.text: We don't teach anything about SEO or interpreting briefs in onboarding, and tbh that's something I want to change. Briefs are a huge area of opportunity for a lot of writers

text: • Do you have goals and timelines for where you want writers to be at the 30, 60, 90 day mark? Yep! We set production milestones - by end of month 1 you'll have written X number of posts. We also set weekly milestones which are softer - by end of week 5, you'll understand the difference between good and bad content ideas

elements.text: Do you have goals and timelines for where you want writers to be at the 30, 60, 90 day mark? Yep! We set production milestones - by end of month 1 you'll have written X number of posts. We also set weekly milestones which are softer - by end of week 5, you'll understand the difference between good and bad content ideas

text: • How structured is the training and how do you deliver it? We're 100% remote so our training is largely async, run through our HRIS. There are videos and reading materials. Plus the new hires go to flipped workshops throughout their first month, and have formal touchpoints with managers, editors, onboarding buddies, leadership and other new hires

elements.text: How structured is the training and how do you deliver it? We're 100% remote so our training is largely async, run through our HRIS. There are videos and reading materials. Plus the new hires go to flipped workshops throughout their first month, and have formal touchpoints with managers, editors, onboarding buddies, leadership and other new hires

text: Once youre out of onboarding, we have things like SEO training, coaching workshops, and live training sessions. One thing we're really missing is an LMS to connect the dots and have people organise their own learning journeys. That's a 2022 thing!

elements.text: Once youre out of onboarding, we have things like SEO training, coaching workshops, and live training sessions. One thing we're really missing is an LMS to connect the dots and have people organise their own learning journeys. That's a 2022 thing!

text:
I'm just thinking this through for ours now. My instinct is that for non-professionals they should be super-structured, with some room for improvisation within that structure. Unless your hosts have a tonne of charm or experience, they're probably going to have a hard time keeping things moving otherwise.

A clear structure also gives you a repeatable format, so it's easier to get into a nice cadence.

What do you think <@U02AJEY8ACW>?

elements.text:
